title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient Care amendment to provide hospital and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. Veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War are eligible for hospital and nursing home care, even if there is insufficient medical evidence linking their disability to the exposure. Veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War are eligible for hospital and nursing home care, even without sufficient medical evidence linking their disability to the exposure. Amendments have been made to expand outpatient care eligibility. Amendments have been made to expand outpatient care eligibility for veterans, including care for disabilities before December 31, 1994. Amendments have expanded outpatient care eligibility for veterans, including care for disabilities before December 31, 1994, specifically for veterans who served in the Southwest Asia theater of operations during the Persian Gulf War and may have been exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards. Amendments to expand outpatient care eligibility for veterans include care for disabilities related to service in the Southwest Asia theater of operations during the Persian Gulf War, even if there is insufficient medical evidence to link the disability to exposure to toxic substances or environmental hazards. Medical services may not be provided for disabilities found to have resulted from causes other than the specified exposure. The amendments expand outpatient care eligibility for veterans, including disabilities related to service in the Southwest Asia theater of operations during the Persian Gulf War. Medical services may not be provided for disabilities found to have resulted from causes other than the specified exposure. Effective August 2, 1990, veterans can request reimbursement for amounts paid to the United States under specific sections of title 38. The amendments allow veterans to request reimbursement for healthcare expenses related to potential exposure to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Effective August 2, 1990, veterans can seek reimbursement for hospital care, nursing home care, or outpatient services provided by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Act allows veterans to seek reimbursement for healthcare expenses related to potential exposure to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Veterans can request reimbursement for care or services provided by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs before the enactment of the Act. The Act extends certain healthcare and other authorities for veterans, including eligibility for care related to exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and sexual trauma counseling. The Act extends healthcare authorities for veterans, including eligibility for sexual trauma counseling and maintaining a regional office in the Philippines. The Act extends healthcare authorities for veterans, including eligibility for sexual trauma counseling and maintaining a regional office in the Philippines. Amendments are made to various sections of title 38, United States Code, changing deadlines to December 31, 1994. The Act extends healthcare authorities for veterans, including eligibility for sexual trauma counseling and maintaining a regional office in the Philippines. Amendments are made to various sections of title 38, United States Code, changing deadlines to December 31, 1994. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The Act aims to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The Act allows the Secretary to share health-care resources with State veterans facilities, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The term 'health-care resource' is defined broadly to include any health-care service and support/administrative resources. The Act allows the Secretary to share health-care resources with State veterans facilities, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. This includes specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other health-care facilities. The Act allows the Secretary to share health-care resources with State veterans facilities, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. This includes specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other health-care facilities for mutual use. The Secretary can share health-care resources with State veterans facilities, including specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other health-care facilities for mutual use. The Secretary may enter into agreements to avoid duplicating resources or to ensure Department resources allocated for veterans' care are used effectively.
